36235107.review:
I bounced off of this when it was still a pre-Super Meat Boy, indie .exe. Not sure what's changed between then and now, but the game behaves virtually the same - so I must be a bigger person.

There aren't many "platformers" (platformers?) that demand such arcade-level mastery from the user. The skills you develop while playing Flywrench are not only mechanical, but translate to perception as well. A kind of neuroplasticity that teaches you to interpret your form-as-locomotion-against-obstacles and pivoting on a dime every 1/10th of a second.

The music is rad. The visuals call back to spectrum/vector style linework. The skills are real. Flywrench is for those who dig microloops that demand mastery. Flywrench is for those who are proud to be the best.

Like Super Meat Boy, a tight experience wrapped in a sexy package. Minimal controls, clean level design, and a surprisingly stellar soundtrack, it continued to surprise. 'Seasoned gamers' likely won't get more than 1-2 hours more out of the campaign but you will be glued to your seat for the entire duration. 

I have yet to dip into Time Trials or the Editor, but at £4.99 for the campaign alone I can confidently recommend Flywrench.

34115617.review:
Flywrench (the original, not this remake) is a downright cult classic/hidden gem, and is one of my all time favorite games. Come one day I see that Messhof is remaking it, and I perk up. I saw the trailer, but rather than getting my hype going instead I felt as if it was a letdown: The music was different, the aesthetic was completely changed, the awesome feeling was seemingly absent. I became sceptical, and I decided I'd wait before trying it out. Then I guess I just forgot about it as I never picked it up for a good year or two.

Eventually I saw it had gone on sale and I decided I'd pick it up, as I still remembered the original fondly. My fears that it would be a disappointment seemed to be eroding away, at least partially. The music was just as grating and unfitting as I had dreaded, but thankfully I turned it off and enjoyed myself a bit more. Come a few hours later And I'd beaten it. Much like its predecessor, it's a rather short game. But it's also meant to be played over and over, practiced and perfected.

Flywrench's story is quite rudimentary: You are presumably some nondescript hacker or something and you are infiltrating a security system via a little flying bug that changes colors to pass through gates... Yeah it doesn't make a ton of sense but it's not essential to the game itself anyways and can be freely skipped at your leisure. The strongest aspect is its core gameplay: You flap to not only go up but to turn red and pass through red walls. You let go to fall and be white to pass through white walls. You roll to turn green and become bouncy as well as passing through... well you get the idea. The complexity and challenge comes from learning this subversion of traditional "platforming" mechanics, and applying how each mechanic affects how you move and when you need to use a specific ability to pass through its corresponding gate. It can be difficult to wrap your head around, but once you ge the hang of it its quite enjoyable, and the game does an excellent job of using simple levels to teach you the basics as well as subtle nuances about the mechanics, while doing nothing to hinder experienced players who will blast through them no problem.

That's well and good, but what really makes the game sing is the level design. As I mentioned before the opening levels are excellent tutorials, and later the complexities of the game's' mechanics pile upon each other as new mechanics are introduced in each subsequent world, and each word does a superb job exploring ways to make each and every one of those mechanics interesting and challenging while never compromising its fairness to you, the player. The game doesn't feel like it's cheating against you; Each level might be hard, but they are short enough that you don't lose much by screwing up. The game effectively sets up a promise: A promise that every level will be short sweet and to the point; A simple and straightforward challenge to overcome before quickly moving on to the next one. And unlike games like Super Meat Boy, the game doesn't break that promise by eventually becoming bogged down with long, frustratingly tedious gauntlet levels which have way more obstacles than should be fair, too many chances to screw up, and a habit of wasting your time. (With only one exception; The final level)

It's a very simple platforming challenge game, but with a clever twist on that formula and a lot more hidden complexity than you might realize. Also a level editor and workshop support give the game a bit more longevity than is really needed, but is a welcome addition nonetheless. Buy it on sale, shoot through it in an afternoon, and enjoy yourself.

32836021.review:
First set of levels - Hey I'm getting the hang of thi...oops, I died. Not to worry since I don't do it that much

Next set of levels - Hmm, this level is becoming a bit of a pain now....

Last set of levels - [b]WHY AM I DYING AT THE START OF THE LEVEL AGAIN AFTER PLAYING IT FOR 15 MINS??![/b]

¬¬¬¬¬¬¬¬¬¬.


In all seriousness, a fantastic game made by the same developer who made Nidhogg. 

[b]Gameplay[/b] - It slowly introduces you into each game mechanic individually as you progress to which it combines them later on to give you that bit of a "bang your head on the desk for 20 hours because you are stuck on the same level" challenge. The mechanics force you to actively think and switching to the right colour for the specific gate. I actually played the original version of the game so I knew what i was getting myself into but wow, this full version is superior.

[b]Music[/b] - Flywrench's soundtracks contains some gentle but booming beats which will keep you focused on the game (Probably...It did for me). I'd have to say that this soundtrack is up there with some other popular games. Favourite song has to be "Kuh Lida - Left Lane Right Brain". 

[b]Community[/b] - The level editor is an awesome addition to add to the game as it allows other players to anger others by letting them play their "impossible" levels. Not to mention that the developer himself also created some additional levels to which I haven't played as of yet (Still cooling down from some of the intense levels in the main game) but I'm certain that I'll need some paracetamols for those when I play them.

If I had to give the game a rating, I don't think I could as it's that unique and enjoable, numbers don't mean anything and I believe that it's an experience that everyone should explore themselves and find their comfort zone with. Another of life's adventures. Cheers for the fantastic game.

32207015.review:
Flywrench is an AWESOME hardcore/quick reflexes "platformer" game. The soundtrack is killer, and the fast-paced gameplay is very addictive. 

For those who are still on the fence after reading other reviews, let me mention two interesting features that really sold me on this game:

1. Helmet Mode: There is a "helmet mode" which makes most levels much easier. You can find this mode under "Options." This is a great design choice, as it gives you another option if you're stuck or temporarily frustrated by the difficulty of a certain section. Another nice perk is that there are separate leaderboards for normal and helmet modes, so you can compete in multiple ways.

2. Level Editor: The level editor in Flywrench is wonderfully simple to use. It's great fun playing around with the design elements to create levels/planets and then testing your creations.

29389464.review:
Flywrench is a cool game with a cool concept and atmosphere. I'm going to go in depth about this game, because I had fun with it up until a certain point. Flywrech is a type of puzzle game focused on movement and momentum. It achieves this by allowing you a limited degree of control over your character: you can freely move left and right, but you remain constantly falling and need to "flap" by pressing a button. You can press it rapidly to "fly" upward and by leaning your character in the other directions you can maintain movement to a certain degree. Additionally; flapping also changes your characters color, switching from white to red as you press or hold the button. This affects how fast you move directionally as well, along with a third button that allows you to turn green and move similarly to a rubber ball.  By having colored barriers that can only be passed if you're a matching color to them: Flywrech begins to shape up as a unique way to move through obstacles.

It's similar to the Super Meatboy brand of game. That makes sense as I noted that the creator of this game was originally a contributer to the Newgrounds community and the character "Flywrench" makes an appearence in Meatboy. (I'm unfamiliar to the degree of which the creator is involved with the creators of other Newgrounds related games; google it for info if you're interested). In each level there's a startpoint and an endpoint. Fail the level and you're sent back to the startpoint. There are no collectables, and it's a very straight-forward game. However, I feel compelled to note that Flywrech contains a difficulty curve that ruins the experience of anyone less than a hardened gamer. I know a lot of people disregard the notion that there are games that are too hard, and that most people need to "git gud", but that isn't what I mean. The levels up till the last world, Mercury, felt fair and gave relative variety to design and challenge. Mercury does not. The difficulty curve spikes harshly towards the end of the game, to almost Cave Story level. Most of the Mercury levels add challenges that cause you to rush when you normally would try to balance your movements and think, and having imprecise movement centered on momentum ruins any sense of challenge as you don't have enough time to react to anything that comes near. There is an easy mode that you can activate, but it only blocks a certain color of wall and most of the challenges on Mercury do not involve the color of that particular barrier. So it won't help you very much. This kind of ruined the experience for me, as Flywrenches atmosphere felt more reserved and dreamy with a mix of urgency that never felt outright disasterous (especially the music; dreamy electric tones overlayed with the occasional voice noise).
Flywrench has a cool concept. You play as a spaceship or hacking tool that needs to make it to the center of the solar system. You pass through satellites as the levels and slowly increase the signal to make it to closer planets. There's indication that you're doing something more surreal as an instructor gives wisdom each time you unlock a new planet. This adds to the dream-like state that the game conveys through its visuals of clashing colors. As of now, I have not seen the end of the game because of the difficulty curve; you need to clear all the levels to access the final area of the Sun. But I felt engaged and enjoyed it enough to go back and mess around with some of the other features that unlock as you progress, including palette swaps and a Level Editor that allows you to make your own planets and zones. There is also a Time Trial mode for the exellently skilled. Not only that, but there is an option to "unlock everything" which I can only imagine unlocks the rest of the game defeating the purpose of struggling through the levels. However, it is nice to see that the developers thought ahead of the fact that the game gets incredibly hard towards the end.
Overall, I'd say Flywrench is worth your money. It's short, but fun and most of the time you aren't to mad about being stuck on a certain level. It's a unique game, and a good one at that!

29309935.review: I dont often do this, but I had to leave a review for this game. It's a little hard to lock down to a genre, but as someone who loves completing masochistic platformers (Bit Trip series, Super Meat Boy style) this game was right up my alley. The difficulty curve can be a little staggering, I completed the first 7 worlds in about 3 hours, but the last two have taken me quite a bit more head smashing. The editor makes for great replayability, but its the actual gameplay that made this game deeply satisfying. Best described as the physics of Flappy Bird on crack cocaine, with unforgiving rules, but quick respawns, if you can navigate the levels of Venus Mercury and the Sun, you're in a good crowd. This game is well worth the money, on sale or no, and a great timesink for the crowd who need to hate themselves around the 2000 death mark.

29283451.review:
The game is a little bit like Balloon Kid, but abstract and rediculously difficult. You tap on button to 'flap' and another to 'spin'. Navigating is all about mastering how each mode moves while navigating a maze of colored barriers.

I was going to wait until I'd completed the game before reviewing, but that's just not going to happen. I have 11 more levels left on Mercury before the Sun unlocks and the difficulty has gone beyond my ability to keep up. I did complete the game years ago before it came to Steam, but I believe the levels were a little different in that version. I played this version entirely on Steam Controller via Link to stress test latency. I tried moving over to keyboard on my desktop and I still can't complete it there.

Amazing soundtrack, great visual style, brilliant controlls. If you like fast skill based games like N+ and Super Meat Boy it doesn't get much better. Good luck!

29004504.review:
抖M和手残党的福音！[strike]（大误）[/strike]
《飞行扳手》是一款极简风格的平台动作类独立游戏。玩家名为6802，你的任务就是驾驶一个扳手（其实应该是飞船但是不知道游戏名字为啥取扳手）循着一个信号从太阳系外围向内心进发寻找一种金属。最终在那里，你能见证物质和时间以一种很奇妙的状态表达出来......[spoiler] （这游戏的字体不知道是啥看起来贼蛋疼）[/spoiler]
好吧剧情不重要，受虐的过程才是关键。
游戏早在07年就有过DEMO，09年在kickstarter上众筹，还作为额外解锁在《超级食肉男孩》里面出现过，最终才在15年得以发行。
历经波折的发售当然带来的是无尽的......折磨。跟食肉男孩类似，该游戏对玩家的时机把握和快速反应能力要求极高。尽管只有两个键+方向键，玩家在控制扳手静止，摆动和旋转这几个不同状态的过程里同时还要对平衡，重力和惯性有所考虑。不同的状态对应着不同的颜色，而对应的颜色则能让你穿过一道道“门”，最终抵达终点。
当然对于极限玩家[strike]（睾丸）[/strike]来说游戏提供的170关可能不够耍，创意工坊的提供也是一个锻（折）炼（磨）自己和朋友的不错方式。
最后值得称道的一点就是游戏的原创电子乐非常精良（虽然可能在同一关死了几百次后觉得就不那么友善了）。
[strike] 不知道为啥肉男死几次就玩不下去但是这个被虐了5个小时依然觉得很带感呢......[/strike]
最后还得加一条光敏性癫痫警告：该游戏带有大量闪烁画面和效果。反正我连续玩了俩小时整个人都不太好了......

24324930.review:
This game probably has the most precise and awesome control scheme of any game I've played. It's hypnotising, along with it's fantastic soundtrack.

The main game is relatively short and I found most levels could be completed in just a couple of tries. The last few levels were the only challenging ones, and it could have been made to get harder still. I found the final level in the game surprisingly easy and forgiving (the world prior was more of a challenge). The included level editor mostly solves this, but it would have been nice for some more official challenging levels.

I completed the game in under 2 hours on my first playthrough. The game is far less difficult than some reviewers seem to be suggesting, as I'm not particularly good at games. See my 2 hours playtime and Lightspeed achievement for proof.

24267719.review: Let me count the ways. . . tight controls; sexy art style; intuitive, novel gameplay; bitesized-yet-nefarious level design; infectious soundtrack; surrealist narrative interjections; hours and hours of story and custom level content; that unparalleled feeling when you pass through an insane gate sequence for the first time. Yeah, this game is up there with Dustforce and Super Meat Boy for indie platformers in my book. My one complaint is that the difficulty curve's a little whacked. It took some time for me to feel genuinely challenged, and when I hit Mercury, it basically blindsided me. Aside from that, Flywrench is a near-perfect experience that is 100% worth your time.

21684005.review:
This game is so good. It is one of the best platformer-y things, up there with Super Meat Boy, N, and Super Mario Brothers.

That said, it is not directly comparable. Rather than standard platforms, it is more manoevering your flywrench ship thing through space, which is set up like levels. The controls are super tight, and if you die, you know it's on you (well, I personally think so, anyway).

The main thing that makes this game unique is the main mechanic. When no buttons are pressed, you are white. When holding one action button, you turn red, which makes you flap and gives you momentum. Pressing the second action button makes you turn green, and you can bounce of walls. There are barriers that you can pass through, white, red and green, To get through them, you have to be the right colour. But, for example, when you turn red to go through a red barrier, you also flap, so that could mess you up, and so on. There are pink boundaries you can't even bounce off, too. There is more things that come in to change up the gameplay, but I'll let you discover it. My first playthough was about 4-5 hours, but my fastest run was about an hour.

One last thing is this is a great level editor. It is super easy to use, and I have made a level pack. I usually can't stand level editors (though there probably are other exceptions).

It is way more straightforward when it is you playing it, but yeah, it is incredible. It is my favourite game to come out of 2015. You will like it, unless you don't.

21422645.review:
I've played this game several times at this point. It's like the trial and error kind of difficulty you find in Super Meat Boy, which I eventually lost interest in, but with a play-style and control scheme I hadn't really seen before, and it's really stuck with me.
If you like difficult level-to-level platform(y) games, buy it. It's cheap.

21417498.review:
I was drawn to this game for two reasons: first I thoroughly enjoyed Nidhogg (developed by the same people), and second I love execution based gameplay like Dustforce or Trackmania where you replay a level over and over trying to perfect it, but unfortunately Flywrench lands far from the fun experience of hitting the retry button while telling yourself “I won’t mess up this time!”. Instead the “flywrench” you play as is hard to control, the smallest misstep leads to an unrecoverable death, and the levels become ruthlessly unforgivable at the end, but beyond any mechanical  fault, the game simply wasn't fun for me in the same way as Dustforce or Trackmania is.

The basic goal of the game is to navigate small quick levels by flapping your flywrench to stay aloft while using the joystick to glide from side to side. The levels start off pretty simple but quickly expand with different mechanics, the most prominent being dodging purple barriers while pressing certain buttons to pass through colored barriers. But unfortunately not matter how much I played, I could never control the flywrench to the proficiency needed to precisely navigate stages without touching a barrier or the walls (which starts bouncing you all over the place and is nearly impossible to recover from before you hit something that will kill you), it feels like a precision platformer with terribly unresponsive controls.

When I first started playing, I didn’t mind the controls so much because the levels were really short and there wasn't much that could kill you, but about halfway through, the levels started getting longer and the path that you need to navigate smaller, but I still persevered hoping something would click and that I would eventually get better, but any improvement I showed was far outstripped by the ramp in difficulty of the levels until I gave up after completing every level up to 19/21 Mercury. And that was it, I couldn't win those last three levels and couldn't muster any interest to keep trying; I wasn't having any fun, so I quit.

Overall the game has some potential if you are into really hard and unforgiving games, but most of the time when I died, I didn’t feel it was my fault. Instead it felt like it was the the difficult controls and the unforgiving level design that was to blame, this made it frustrating to play. When I did manage to complete a level it felt like it was due to luck more than any skill on my part, sapping any sense of achievement from winning and not providing any incentive to continue on. So unless you really know you are the kind of person who loves throwing themselves at insurmountable challenges, I recommend passing this game bye. There are other games in the Steam, there is bound to be another that will love you back, beacause Flywatch sure won’t.

21374796.review: Played 90 minutes, failed 1000 times, 70 levels beaten. That's my game.

This game is addicting. The controls are extremely intuitive and the levels are fair. The soundtrack is nice too. I finished the game after  a bit more than two and a half hours, which is adequate value for this type of game. There are also Editor levels, which is a nice addition.

Unfortunately the developers claim to support saving date in the Steam Cloud, which is not the case.
The game does "sync", but no data actually gets uploaded to the cloud during that process.

It does not help that the saves are located in the appdata folder, making them for less tech-literate people basically inaccessible.

20020486.review:
2D fast-paced aerial platformer with a great soundtrack to complement the abstract visual aesthetics. Each set of levels (planets) introduces either a new mechanic or twist which changes the flow of levels, making you think of both how to 'solve' the level and then shortly how quickly you can solve it. Flywrench quickly goes from straight-forward to aggressively hard for most planets until the last few planets, where your skills at platforming and patience are truly tested.

Technically solid with high frame-rate and fine-tuned input control, allowing one to switch between modes almost instantaneously, which for advanced players is key to getting fast times. Also works well with the Steam Controller where using A to jump and RG (Right Grip) to flip green allowed for even faster reaction times when dealing with level obstacles.

Oh yeah, the soundtrack is great. Worth saying twice.

19985940.review:
I absolutely loved the platforming aspects of this game, and it's quickness to put you right back to the beginning so you can keep trying and trying until you break your keyboard, despite the fact that it was already broken from the blood, sweat, and tears you soaked it with beating the previous level.

This game also has an amazing soundtrack!

10/10 would buy a new keyboard again

19951598.review: Every time I get past a level is a rush.  Really fun game with an exceedingly comfy aesthetic.

19935579.review:
Good music and a e s t h e t i c s. Very satisfying to play.

19450490.review:
Flywrench is a sublime experience. Everything about it feels [i]so good[/i] and completely natural. The wrench (let's call it that) has among the most fun physics I've experienced in a game, moving gracefully but with the precision you need.

The game has a perfectly crafted difficulty curve, introducing you to mechanics and letting you figure out techniques without telling you explicitly, eventually culminating in some pretty hard levels that take a while to get down. We're not talking Super Meat Boy level hard, but I had significantly more fun playing Flywrench and never got frustrated, even when I was bashing my head against a wall.

The aesthetic of Flywrench is also superb, with a distinctive and appealing art style that still conveys gameplay easily. Even as a colourblind person I could distinguish the yellow walls and green barriers easily. The white and cyan ones were a little trickier but still distinguishable based on context.

Flywrench's soundtrack is phenomenal and is basically just "What does Orbi like? Put that in there" with a compilation of tracks that all work both thematically and to keep you excited. There's an OST available on [url=https://play.google.com/store/music/album/Various_Artists_Flywrench_OST?id=Bn73afwc5dhvjxy4q2657cmqslm]Google Play[/url]. Sadly it's missing the best song, but hopefully Machinedrum will drop it eventually.

Everything about this game speaks to me on a base level in such a way that I just can't help but be enamored.

19296457.review:
For the sake of my own verbosity and the reader, I've opted to write two reviews: a long form one in which I go into greater detail on Pastebin, here: http://pastebin.com/XMGwBWNB , and a shorter summary of the review here.

Gameplay: Very simplistic mechanics wise, but the depth comes from the controls. Game quite dramatically scales in difficulty toward the end, which can be offputting to some. Overall levels are a lot of fun, and the game is very speedrunnable. I see myself replaying this in the future. 9/10.

Story: Not much in the way of story, so I'm not gonna review that.

Graphics: Very simplistic art style, functional like it needs to be. Game runs at a perfect 60 FPS in gameplay. No windowed resolution presets, but window is freely resizable. 4/5.

Sound: Few original compositions for the game, but picked songs are a really good mix of techno and drum'n'bass. 4/5.

9/0/4/4; 8.5/10.

19274230.review:
Since it's on sale I figured I would write a review. It's been a long time coming anyways.

In a way, Flywrench is similar to precision platformers such as Super Meat Boy (it was even an unlockable character in meatboy). However, in many other ways it is not. For one, the game isn't a platformer, it's hard to even label the game under a specific genre. Flywrench is its own very unique thing, and plays like no other game I've played. The game has a fantastic sense if flow to it making moving through the game a really enjoyable experience. This sense of flow has contributed to me spending 60+ hours doing time trials and speedruns in this game, as moving through the game quickly is one of the most satisfying experiences I have had with a game. 

I do personally have a lot of problems with the game though. Firstly, I personally feel that the levels are way to short. This gets fixed later in the game however early levels only take 1-3 seconds to clear which makes clearing them feel really trivial and a bit silly. Some of the levels especially are more about getting the angle or bounce the game wants rather than taking any actual skill from the player. Get past the first half of the game however and it really starts to pick up with the final set of levels being one of my favourite parts of any game. Secondly, the game is very short. Don't let the hours on my account fool you, a first playthrough of the game will only take the player 2-4 hours, depending on their skill level. While there is a lot of extra content with time trials and the level editor, if that sort of thing does not interest you there's very little to keep you playing a long time. I would personally say that with how enjoyable the game is, 4 hours of gameplay is worth full price, but I understand that this differs greatly from person to person.

Overall Flywrench is a fantastic package. Despite it's issues it remains the best experience I have had in 2015 and I will likely continue to play it well into the future. Unique gameplay, interesting level design, and fantastic music and presentation make this game something special. If you interested in these sorts of games, I highly suggest you check this out.

Flywrench is brutal, fast, simple and precise. It's a game about quick reflexes and repeated failures. Learning the game was fun, but playing the player created levels was a nightmare.

18105942.review:
Very fun, yet exremely challenging. If you don't like hard but fair games like Super Meat Boy, then this game might not be for you. If you've played the old freeware version, this version seems to have a lot more levels, as well as all entirely different levels.

IMPORTANT: If your computer has very low specs, or if it is very slow, the game seems to deal with that by slowing down. So, if your computer can't handle the game, from what people are saying, it seems that the game will slow down and feel "floaty," which makes the game a lot easier, too easy to be very much fun.

Also, Messhof, the developer, is very active in the community forums, answering questions and responding to feedback. For example, I started a thread in the forums asking if there was any way to replay the cutscenes. There wasn't at the time, but less than 5 days later, Messhof added this feature to the game in an update, and responded to my thread saying that he had added it.

The level editor is also quite nice and intuitive.

9/10
Well worth the $10.

18032204.review:
Although the graphics and controls are simple, Flywrench is a fun game. 

The main mechanics in Flywrench involve avoiding obstacles while also occasionally shifting the color/form of your ship in order to pass through obstacles of the same color. While the gameplay is simple, requiring only a couple buttons, the game does a great job creating interesting levels. Most of the levels take between five to twenty seconds to complete but you will die a lot as you work out how to avoid all of the obstacles.

Games where you die constantly usually frustrate me but due to the short length of the levels it's not so bad since you lose little progress when you die. Also a majority of the game is moderately difficult. Only the last two or three worlds become really challenging. 

If the idea behind the game doesn't interest you, you probably won't like the game. If the concept does interest you though I think you will should have quite a bit of fun with game.

Note: I received a free review copy of Flywrench. Other than the free review copy I received no other compensation and the free review copy had no impact of the content of this review.

[url=http://www.geekyhobbies.com/flywrench-indie-action-game-review/] Read My Full Review[/url]

18024700.review:
This is one of those games that is just plain fun. It felt a lot like hotline miami, where you just zone out to the AMAZING soundtrack and fly through challenging levels, but the second you die you are immediately back in the action.

Usually in games level design ramps up as you go through, meaning as levels get really hard, you will tend to try at a level for 10 minutes, just to beat it and move on to an even harder level without any sort of break. This game combats that by still leaving in challenging, but not extremely difficult levels in between really hard ones, so you have a minute or two to relax (sort of) and listen to the music.

Speaking of the music, the soundtrack is really just crazy good. the DnB, and electro in this game is some of the best I have ever heard! I stand by my reference to Hotline Miami, as while it is completely different, it has a very similar vibe.

My computer accidentically deleted my saves after I was about 3 planets in, then after playing almost to the sun, my computer decided to RESTORE MY OLD SAVE setting me back to the 3rd planet :(, so no I am playing again and I am still loving every second of it! (minus a few levels that were just really tedious).

The one feature that this game is really lacking is the ability to adjust sound effect volume. I want to be able to turn the music way up, and only be able to barely hear the SFX, but the only option is to turn SFX off completely. The game is still pretty new, so I hope this is added in a patch.

EDIT:
So this game is really extremely fun, and has the darksouls quality of making you die a lot, but you always know it's your fault (never the game's), and that you can do better... untill the second to last planet (each planet is a series of 20 or so levels). Once you reach murcury, all the levels put you on some rediculously short timer, and it become less about skill, and more about memorizing the exact pixel perfect sequence of button pushes in order to get through the level.

These timers take the forms of pinweels that "Push" you through a level, or gates that only stay open X ammount of seconds after you trigger them to open, often closing RIGHT as you are passing through them. The pinweels are especially frustrating because not only do they push you from the back, but if you are going to fast (because, idk, your being chased by a SPINNING WALL OF DEATH) then you will hit the front side of the pinweel and die! This causes a margin of error that is so small it's almost feels impossible, like where the keys on my keyboard/controller physically cannot actuate fast enough to get through the obsticals.

The game was still REALLY fun up untill Murcury though, so it's still worth a buy

18023009.review: Flywrench takes the essence of precision platformers and presents it through a satisfying movement scheme. Combining your two moves (flap and spin) with positioning and momentum gives you a deep level of control. It's fast and sensitive, so experimenting and studying level layouts is a must for success. Excellent presentation too - the visuals and soundtrack amplify the basic-yet-intense action.

Came through a long way in its development, but it´s definitely a game I would recommend to anyone who likes the genre.
9/10

17889104.review:
Much like Nidhogg, Messhof takes a simple game mechanic and creates a challenging game that fans of Velocibox, Superhexagon, etc. will enjoy.  In addition, fans of Nidhogg's soundtrack will also love this game as it once again features a pounding soundtrack with returning Daedelus as lead music designer, while featuring additional highly influential electronic music artists.

This game will likely take players 3-4 hours to complete, but the game offers a degree of replayability for those wanting to do time trials, or for those wanting to use the in-game level editor to make their own levels. 

I believe the biggest negative for this game is the exponential increase in difficulty towards the latter part of the game.   My biggest critique of the game is, rather truly exploring and using the new obstacles to their fullest in each planet and gradually scaling difficulty, the game holds back until you get to Mercury.  On average, it took me maybe 10-15 mins to completely clear a planet. I would even often clear levels on my first try. However, upon getting to Mercury one level would take me up to 15-20 mins to complete.  Don't get me wrong, I loved Mercury because it really showcases Messhof's creativity, but at the same time why couldn't we have more of these levels?

Another minor gripe with the game is that difficulty isn't presented through use of in-game mechanics, but rather exploiting the limitations of the keyboard. Levels in Mercury often have you going diagonal, which is inherently more difficult and imprecise than using a controller. I would've like the game to be more challenging through use of spinning and fluttering than trying to awkwardly move sideways. But, as I've said this is only a minor gripe.

Overall I was very satisfied playing the game and I will be returning to it. Time for time trials!

17782850.review:
I had no idea that this was slated for a Steam release (or any kind of release for that matter), but this was an insta-buy because I played the original waaay back after playing Super Meat Boy (didn't we all play Flywrench, Jumper, Mighty Jill-Off, Runman, etc. after meeting them in Super Meat Boy — at least if we hadn't met them before?), and while the game kicked my ass back then, I've gotten older and better so here we are for round two...

This game is fast and hard (like Brannigan's law and Brannigan's love) and frantic, and it's still kicking my ass but this time around I at least feel like I'm giving the game a run for its money. One of the things that makes the game feel so hectic is the fact that there is no way to take it easy for a while — not even for a tenth of a second — and try to assess the situation. You're constantly getting hurled around in space with no backwards thrusters ... and you WILL enjoy it. But seriously though, in terms of speed this game makes Super Hexagon look like Hello Kitty compared to Sonic. And it's friggin' awesome!

Such fast. Much satisfying. Very soundtrack. So colors. Many recommends. Wow!

17726515.review:
From developer Messhof, who you may know from another game - [i]NidHogg[/i]. Like [i]NidHogg[/i], [i]Flywrench[/i] is also overpriced, although there is certainly more content and replayabilty. I think this game (which used to be free, with less content) should be priced between 3-5$.

Essentially, you navigate an 'L' shaped character through various obstacles. You have the ability to turn green or red which helps break through like-colored barriers. You will bounce off walls and die hundreds of times. It really reminds me of [i]VVVVVV[/i] (I believe they were made in the same time period?). Some people compare it to [i]Super Meat Boy[/i], but I don't really see that. [i]SMB[/i] was strictly a platformer - and had better art, storyline, and debatably music (as did [i]VVVVVV[/i]).

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Interesting novelty of changing colors to break through walls, creating a puzzle-like experience
+Music is good
+Fun enough for short spurts

[b]Meh:[/b]
=Storyline (if you can call it that) has potential, but is not really all that engaging

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Too expensive - I still feel burned over [i]Nidhogg[/i]
-I mean there are millions of these little quirky games that are generally free, overall there is not enough here to justify that price tag

[b]I'd wait for at least a half-price sale.[/b]

17708227.review:
I died over 500 times in my first hour. Glorious.

If you get any amount of enjoyment from such wonderfully frustrating games as N, VVVVVV or Super Meatboy, you owe it to yourself to get Flywrench.

Every control and visual element is impeccably precise, meaning you have full contol over the incredible twitch gameplay. You respawn in an in instant meaning you can happily die a hundred times a minute and still keep trying.

Also it has a beast of a soundtrack.

17705519.review:
tl:dr This game is great.

A very elegantly designed....platformer?  There aren't any platforms to speak of but I can't think of another way to describe Flywrench.   You're a small white rectangle with the ability to flap yourself to ascend while turning red and tumble and bounce off walls while turning green.  You pass harmlessly through barriers of the color you currently are, whereas you die immediately if you hit a different-color wall or barrier.  The controls are extremely tight and that's good because this game quickly becomes very challenging.  Your (numerous) failures don't annoy however because upon death you respawn immediately and try again.   Also helpful is the fact that new worlds (each one introduces a new mechanic) are unlocked once a set number of stages are completed so if you find a stage particularly difficult, you can skip it and come back later without hampering progression.   It evokes both Super Meat Boy and N+ and comes highly recommended to anyone who likes difficult stage-based platform challenge games.

17703875.review:
I picked this up on a whim since I loved Nidhogg and I'm very happy that I did. The game hits the perfect balance being satisfyingly difficult while not getting too frustrating, it just feels really good to play (I actually wandered away from writting this at least 5 times to play for a bit more). 

The aesthetic of the game is really strong as well, the glitchy visuals are much more appealing than they initally appear and the various unlockable themes are welcome additions (even the one called RETINA_BURN). The music is especially noteworthy, this is probably the best game soundtrack since Hotline Miami, it might even be better. 

If you have any interest in hard games or glitchy visuals and music I would highly recommend picking this up. The soundtrack alone is worth the price of the game. Between this and Nidhogg Messhof has an amazing track record, I hope this game gets as much exposure as Nidhogg because it definitely deserves it.

17702269.review:
Flywrench is slick in every sense of the word.  Tight controls (I am playing on a gamepad) support the simple yet addictive gameplay that involves changing Mr. Wrench's color, velocity, and momentum in order to navigate tons of levels.  The game plays fast and the strong soundtrack allows you to slip into a zen state trying over and over to beat a given level.  Finally, the clean interface and readable graphics (with unlockable color schemes) produce a simple, yet impressive, presentation - with some goofy story 'scenes' occasionally butting into the game unnecessarily.

The game also has an additonal time trial mode with leaderboards and an included level editor (which doesn't seem too daunting!) that will hopefully add to the game's longevity over time.  All in all, Flywrench is a pretty sweet game.

17701896.review: It's like a bouncehouse mixed with a rave

17701787.review:
This game has a really cool art style and unique gameplay that make it really fun. It's also really fast-paced, with each level taking place seconds after the last. The music is catchy as hell to boot.

I have some problems with it though, mainly with regards to difficulty. The majority of levels I've played so far have been pretty easy, but as soon as you get to world 9 there's a DRASTIC difficulty spike, to the point that I'm not even sure how to progress in one of the levels. The difficulty curve is pretty broken as a result.

All in all, pretty fun game. I can tell I'm gonna be bashing my head into it for weeks!

17701573.review:
This game is very cool. It's hardcadey and wonderful. Controls are super smooth and tight and natural. Restarting is oh but an instant.

The music is fabulous. Daedelus, Baths, and who knows who else that has been affiliated with Anticon at one point or another. And that Postal Service guy. And a bunch of indie musicians. It's all very good.

And daresay I love where the story is going! I'll have to finish it just for that!

Support good indie games, like this one. Do it.

17699749.review:
I like this game. It's entertaining. 

What I LOVE about it though is the music. The music REALLY makes it.

17699475.review: this is one of my favorite games in the whole wide world! beautiful audiovisual presentation, simple & deep mechanics/controls that wire straight into your brain, and a whole pile of class/style that just idk, makes it the best. must-play!

17699280.review: Flywrench is a minimalist space-glitch-ship game and it is incredibly, incredibly well-polished. This is one of the few games I actually don't get frustrated at because the mechanics are so tight and fair. Though the controls seem simple, there's a surprising amount of mastery and depth to the game, with all kinds of levels in the different planets. The level editor feature will be super exciting for the future, with people contributing more and more community-made levels for the game. I highly highly recommend Flywrench. It's a fantastic game and it has one of the best soundtracks out there!

17698956.review: ITS OFF THE FREAKIN' CHAIN DUDES

17697325.review: Messhof's been working on this game for so long now. I was a big fan of the freeware version from back in 2007, and this is an improvement in every way. Fast, tough, smooth, challenging, fair. It has everything you want from a masocore game, as well as having an interesting control scheme and a wonderful trashy glitchy aesthetic. To top it off, there's a Steamworks integrated level editor, which I'm sure will be flooded with neat stuff soon enough. If you like tough games, this is for you.

17696574.review: Got this because I really liked nidhogg, but this is WAYYYY too simple to charge $9 for.  I would maybe pay a dollar for this or play it for free on a website but $9 is outrageous for a game like this.

40729252.review:
Pues es un juego de corte minimalista que reta a tu habilidad, y a tu paciencia. Sobre todo a tu paciencia.

Eres un palo que va flotando en la negrura. Tienes que pasar una especie de laberintos evitando unas rayas. Cada uno tiene un trazado muy distinto al anterior y te pone a prueba de diversas maneras. Para pasar unas líneas rojas tienes que hacerte rojo, para las verdes hacerte verde y así por el estilo. Pero también hay unas como cascadas de lodo que te aceleran y te estropean todo, unas bolas que te disparan gargajos morados y en fin hay una variedad de obstáculos que te harán sudar sangre, sobre todo en el bendito último nivel.

Pros:
-Juego casual.
-No te da nada pero cuando al fin logras pasar una fase sientes que has logrado la meta de tu vida, sobre todo las últimas.
-Hay una historia, creo. Pero equis, no es interesante.
-Con un editor puedes crear tus propios niveles para hacer sufrir a tus amigos.
-No sé si esto es un pro, pero tiene música como Trance, o algo así, yo no sé de eso. Y ni me gusta. Pero como sé que a muchos sí pues lo pongo como pro.
-No hay pantallas de carga, vas a lo que vas.
-Está medio psicodélico.


Ni pros ni contras:
-Está bien frenético.
-Las malditas bolas moradas siempre te atinan como por arte del diablo.
-Vas por diversos planetas pero la verdad todos son iguales estéticamente hablando.
-Lo más difícil es maniobrar la condenada nave, porque va cayendo todo el tiempo y tienes que darle como aletazos para que levante y no mueras pero a veces esos aletazos te hacen estrellarte contra lo que hay arriba aunque tú no tengas la culpa e igual mueres. 

Contras:
-A veces el reto es a tu paciencia porque vas a morir más de mil veces, insisto, sobre todo en Mercurio, bendito sea dios por qué tuvieron que hacer esa fase tan difícil por qué por qué. Dan ganas de romper el teclado.
-Hay fases que realmente no requieren habilidad, sino suerte. Algunas son estúpidamente crueles, ponen tu pericia al límite, y puedes aventarte media hora intentando pasar un caminito lleno de obstáculos. 

Si eres un freak y te sientes pro y te gustan los juegos de habilidad old-school y crees que ya no hay juegos duros porque ahora los niños quieren pura cosa peladita, esto es para ti, cómpralo, además a veces está de oferta. Asegúrate de tener un teclado de repuesto.
